webTitle: BP and Shell face new allegations of rigging oil prices in US lawsuit

fields.standfirst: Companies among five accused by oil traders of repeatedly  trying to rig spot price for Brent crude
fields.body:
BP and Shell have been forced on the defensive by new allegations of price-rigging made in a US lawsuit brought by four oil traders.

The two companies, along with others involved with the oil market, are alleged to have attempted to rig the spot price for Brent crude oil on multiple occasions in the last decade. The court documents list several alleged incidents in which the accusers claim the market price could have been manipulated.

BP and Shell both said they had no comment on the allegations.

One oil industry insider said fixing the price of Brent crude, an important benchmark oil price based on North Sea production, was unlikely because of the competitive nature of spot trading in the oil market. Other insiders dismissed the claims as "four traders trying their luck" and as "frivolous".

Though the cases are not linked, the new suit may have been encouraged by the current European commission investigation into alleged energy market price fixing, and by a whistleblower's claims, in the Guardian, that price-fixing was rife in UK gas markets.

Other companies named in the US lawsuit include Morgan Stanley, the investment bank; the trader Vitol Group; and Trafigura, the oil and metals trader that illegally exported toxic waste which was then dumped by a contractor in Africa. All three declined to comment.

David Kovel, a lawyer for the traders bringing the case, told Bloomberg News, which uncovered the suit: "It's a very obscure market. To outsiders, it can seem impenetrable. Specialists and speciality traders in the market can take advantage of this obscurity."

The suit, which was filed on 4 October in the Manhattan federal court, details instances when the prices of Brent crude and other crudes were at variance, when the traders allege that trades occurred that under and oversold the benchmark.

However, industry people who could not be named said that such instances could arise naturally in the normal run of trading.

The energy industry has come under severe pressure on pricing recently. Allegations of market-fixing in the UK emerged late last year, and have yet to be fully resolved. Some UK energy suppliers have been forced to admit mis-selling, and the price rises – in some cases of more than 10% – announced in the past few weeks by the UK's big six suppliers have prompted outrage.

The plaintiffs in the New York suit are Kevin McDonnell, a former director of Nymex, the New York Mercantile Exchange; Anthony Insinga and Robert Michiels, both independent floor traders; and John Devivo, a seat-holder on the exchange.

webTitle: Blockbuster to close remaining stores as video rental chain calls it quits

fields.standfirst: Once-ubiquitous video rental chain filed for bankruptcy in 2010 and has been unable to compete with Netflix and Redbox
fields.body:
The American strip mall staple Blockbuster is closing its remaining stores by early January, according to parent company Dish.

Dish announced on Wednesday that it would shutter Blockbuster's remaining 300 stores and its distribution centers. As many as 2,800 employees will be laid off according to Reuters.

At its peak, Blockbuster's dominance pushed smaller local rental stores out of business. The chain suffered a similar fate as it was pushed out by online video services like Netflix and the ubiquitous self-service Redbox kiosks.

"This is not an easy decision, yet consumer demand is clearly moving to digital distribution of video entertainment," Dish CEO Joseph Clayton said in the statement. "We continue to see value in the Blockbuster brand, and we expect to leverage that brand as we continue to expand our digital offerings."

Blockbuster filed for bankruptcy in September 2010 and was acquired by Dish Network in April 2011 for $320m. Dish then began gradually closing the 1,700 stores it obtained in the acquisition. The company said it plans to focus its resources on Blockbuster's on-demand and streaming services.

The company said it will also discontinue Blockbuster's DVD-by-mail service in mid-December and that it had already divested the company's international assets, including operations in the UK and Scandinavia.

Dish will keep licensing rights to the brand and its extensive video library and will continue working on Blockbuster's domestic and international franchise operations and relationships. This means about 50 US stores operated by franchisees will remain open.

Hollywood Video, Blockbuster's largest competitor in the pre-streaming era, shuttered its remaining US stores in 2010. Movie Gallery Inc acquired the company in 2005 and filed for bankruptcy twice before closing its remaining stores.

Blockbuster has not said what the future holds for people who have yet to return overdue films.

webTitle: Former Co-operative Bank chairman says ministers backed expansion spree

fields.standfirst: Paul Flowers tells Treasury select committee that politicians including Vince Cable cheered on ill-fated strategy
fields.body:
Politicians actively encouraged the Co-operative Bank in its ambitious five-year expansion spree – a strategy which has resulted in hedge funds forcing the 100-year-old institution to end its mutual ownership – the bank's former chairman has claimed.

In often contradictory and heated exchanges at the Treasury select committee on Wednesday Paul Flowers said that the former City minister Mark Hoban and the business secretary, Vince Cable, had cheered on the ill-fated attempt by the Co-op Bank to buy 631 branches from the Lloyds Banking Group.

Flowers – who is a Methodist minister and was questioned by MPs about his banking credentials – said he resigned as chairman in June 2013 to take responsibility for the £1.5bn capital shortfall that is now being filled through a deal that involves the Co-op Group of supermarkets, undertakers and pharmacies handing a 70% share in the bank to a group of bondholders, led by US hedge funds.

Flowers revealed two other areas of political interest in the bank, apart from the so-called Verde deal to buy the Lloyds branches which collapsed in April 2013 after two years of talks.

He said the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls – a Co-op party MP - had been involved in pushing through legislation to allow the bank to merge with Britannia Building Society in 2009. That deal is now blamed for many of the problems at the enlarged bank. A spokesman for Balls said his support for the so-called Butterfill bill was well-known and the Britannia deal had been done on a commercial basis.

Flowers also revealed that at the Conservative party conference in 2010, Owen Paterson, then Northern Ireland minister, had been involved in trying to encourage the Co-op Bank to rescue the "basket case" of the building society Presbyterian. The bank refused to do so.

Andrew Tyrie, the chairman of the committee, told Flowers his evidence was contradictory and colourful and asserted that his three-year spell as chairman of the bank had tarnished the entire Co-operative movement. Flowers's lack of banking experience – apart from four years beginning in 1968 as a banker – was evidence that "the chairman of a bank must have a good deal of financial experience and expertise", Tyrie said.

Flowers said he took his share of the responsibility for what had gone wrong but failed to impress MPs with his recollections about the size of the bank: "I took responsibility as the chair, but I assume responsibility for what happened lay with all us."

He described the political support from the coalition for the Verde deal as "lovely" – although his evidence caused confusion as the committee had been told by a number of earlier witnesses that politicians had not been involved. He disputed there had been political interference.

"There was not political interference, there was not political pressure but there was political goodwill for the deal to proceed," said Flowers.

Asked if the Treasury was supportive of the Verde deal, he said: "I have absolutely no doubt that was the case."

There was no direct influence on him, he said. But politicians – whose identity he declined to reveal, first on confidentiality grounds, then saying he could not remember – had let it be known that Cable was supportive of the deal as it would create a challenger to the "big four" high street banks. Flowers later said he had been "stupid" to suggest there were confidentiality reasons for not disclosing the names.

Hoban had been in direct telephone contact with Peter Marks, the former chief executive of the overall group, Flowers said. Hoban – who is known to have held 30 meetings to facilitate the deal – offered "pleasure and support" .

Flowers said he had been approved as chairman by the then regulator, the Financial Services Authority, and said he is now semi-retired. "I can conceive in no way in which I would wish to run another financial services institution," said Flowers.

It was not until 2012 that Co-op Bank had realised it had "some quite difficult loans" from Britannia. He admitted he had not initially known about concerns raised by Lloyds about the capital position of the bank during the Verde talks. At a private meeting with KPMG he had concluded it was time to pull out of the long-running discussions.

Lloyds, meanwhile, admitted it had begun an internal review of its currency trading activities as a result of other banks revealing they were co-operating with global regulators over potential manipulation of the £3tn a day market.

webTitle: BAE closure of Portsmouth shipyard prompts political row

fields.bodyText: The coalition has been accused of sacrificing Portsmouth's 500-year-old shipbuilding tradition to save the industry in Glasgow before Scotland's independence referendum, as it unveiled plans for almost 1,800 job losses in the two cities. Philip Hammond, the Conservative defence secretary, said it was "regrettable but inevitable" that BAE Systems' Portsmouth site would have to close, as there would no longer be enough orders to sustain two major military shipyards in the UK. The closure in Portsmouth removes the immediate threat of closure from Glasgow's Scotstoun and Govan yards, although 835 jobs will be lost at those sites as well as at two other locations, in Fife and Bristol. These will be kept open to build three patrol boats while they wait to begin construction on millions of pounds' worth of type 26 warships in 2015. However, ministers faced claims that they were playing politics with UK jobs as Alistair Carmichael, the Scottish secretary, said it would be difficult to award the type 26 work to Scotland if the country voted to leave the UK in 2014. BAE will cut 1,775 jobs in total once its construction of two multibillion-pound aircraft carriers is completed. While Glasgow's two major yards have been protected, shipbuilding will end for good in Portsmouth, with the loss of 940 jobs, bringing the curtain down on a centuries-old industry in the city that built the Tudor warship the Mary Rose. In the House of Commons on Wednesday the defence secretary tried to put a positive spin on the announcement, saying £100m would be spent on upgrading and repairing the naval base at Portsmouth. The city will soon be home to the HMS Queen Elizabeth, HMS Prince of Wales and type 45 destroyers. The government said the decision to close Portsmouth had been taken by the company alone "on the basis of industrial logic" as BAE Systems – the UK's largest defence contractor – said Glasgow was the best location for building the type 26. The move was largely backed by Labour, although the party said it needed to "take time to fully examine the consequences". However, several MPs in the south claimed the government was behind the decision, arguing that Portsmouth had suffered from a political calculation that jobs could more easily afford to be lost in the south than in Glasgow, whose voters are crucial to the outcome of the Scottish referendum next year. Mike Hancock, the independent MP for Portsmouth South, said his constituents had paid a "very heavy price for a slightly cynical manoeuvre", while John Denham, the Labour MP for Southampton Itchen, said southern England has been "sold downriver while the government looks elsewhere". Some Tories questioned whether there had been a tradeoff, with Caroline Dinenage, the MP for Gosport, saying she thought Portsmouth jobs had been sacrificed. "The fact that Scottish jobs have been protected at the expense of those on the south coast, which is an area of equal economic need, for us is devastating and very upsetting," she said. While the decision to save the Glasgow shipyard could help the campaign for Scotland to stay part of the UK, the closure of Portsmouth's site also does not bode well for the electoral prospects of Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, who has a majority of just over 7,000. Mordaunt, a Royal Navy reservist and aide to the defence secretary, has written to BAE Systems to ask why some of the patrol vessels cannot be built in Portsmouth when the city asked for two ships to be built there. Pressed on the issue of English versus Scottish jobs, Hammond said the losses were a "harsh blow" but the decision had been made in the national interest. He stressed that the redundancies in Portsmouth should be seen in light of the 11,000 remaining jobs in the city's ship maintenance industry. It is understood that Vince Cable, the business secretary, has worked with Hammond to provide a support package to Portsmouth and the surrounding area, with aides promising more to come. Vernon Coaker, Labour's shadow defence secretary, said he wanted to know what bearing the independence poll had had on the decision and what would happen to the industry if Scottish votes to leave the UK. Asked about the issue, David Cameron's official spokesman said: "This is a government that always takes decisions based on the national interest. This decision was taken with a view of how we have the best-equipped, best-maintained Royal Navy." The prime minister himself said it had been an "extremely difficult decision" for BAE to close the Portsmouth shipyard, but promised there would still be a lot of work in the city maintaining ships for "many, many years to come". As he explained the closures and job losses, Hammond was also quizzed on the costs of the aircraft carrier programme as he confirmed that the bill had risen by a further £800m to £6.2bn. He said the increase had not come as a surprise and he could not guarantee that the bill would not rise further. Turning his fire on the opposition, Hammond blamed the previous government for placing an order for the aircraft carriers without a final design. The first of the carriers, Queen Elizabeth, is due to begin sea trials towards the end of the decade. A decision will not be taken until 2015 about whether the second carrier, Prince of Wales, will ever be operational; it could be sold or mothballed. The carriers were built by a consortium that included BAE.

webTitle: Forget common sense: bring on the Twitter IPO madness

fields.bodyText: Here we go, then: it's the Twitter flotation. It's a moment when the investment world tosses aside dull yardsticks like profits and cash flow and instead gives a collective shrug and declares: "What the hell, if Facebook is worth $120bn, then $17bn (£10bn) for Twitter can't be that silly, can it?" The flotation will probably proceed swimmingly, of course. Investors seem to have made up their minds that, by Silicon Valley's normal standards, Twitter's hype machine has been vaguely restrained. The impression has been created that, notwithstanding a late rise in the price range, the company's shareholders are not trying to squeeze the last dollar from the sale of a 13% stake. But so what? The Twitter valuation, even if it were cut in half, would be ridiculous if you care about profits and earnings. It has never made any. Indeed, losses for the first nine months of this year widened to $133m from $71m. Yes, revenues may double this year to about $600m, but that is hardly a basis from which to justify a $17bn price-tag. Indeed, we are not even close to discovering whether Twitter can be transformed into an advertising medium without destroying its value in the eyes of users. Facebook may be able to turn itself into an online billboard without provoking a backlash, but that does not mean Twitter can repeat the trick with commercial messages. Users may simply regard a "promoted tweet" as one that should be ignored – which, given the fast and furious nature of the medium, is easy to do. Yes, Twitter is a social phenomenon and will continue to be so. With 200m users, that status is undeniable. But persuading the outside world that $17bn is a reasonable valuation in loss-making form is Twitter's most remarkable achievement.

webTitle: As benefit rules get tougher, the claimant count further loses its credibility

fields.bodyText: The economy is cooking with gas and the claimant-count measure of unemployment proves it. That has been what government supporters have been saying in recent months as the dole queues have shrunk. The number of people claiming jobseeker's allowance fell by 120,000 in the latest three months, a far more rapid decline than shown by the Labour Force Survey, the internationally agreed yardstick for calculating joblessnesss. In truth, it has been impossible to take the claimant count seriously as a guide to the economy since the 1980s, when the then Conservative government changed the methodology 30 times. Only one change led to unemployment going up. The claimant count measures people who are unemployed and eligible to claim benefit. If you are not eligible you don't count. Clearly, there has been some improvement in labour market conditions in recent months. The number of job vacancies is up and the percentage of people employed has risen, if not yet to the levels seen before the recession began. But there has also been a significant tightening of welfare rules, leading to more people being sanctioned and losing their benefits. Since the new regime was introduced last October, the number of adverse decisions (people deprived of JSA for between four weeks and 36 months) was almost two and a half times as high as in the decade 2000-2010. Ministers say that they are providing help as well as penalties, and that those coming off the count are finding jobs. This seems unlikely. The economy is just about capable of finding employment opportunities for a workforce that is increasing in size all the time. Demand for labour remains weak. Many of those sanctioned for minor transgressions, such as failing to show up for an appointment on time, will go back on JSA. The experience of other countries, such as the US, is that others will disappear from the system altogether and become destitute. How that is supposed to plug them back into the labour market, the avowed intention of the toughened up system, is not immediately obvious.

fields.headline: As benefit rules get tougher, the claimant count further loses its credibility
fields.body:
The economy is cooking with gas and the claimant-count measure of unemployment proves it. That has been what government supporters have been saying in recent months as the dole queues have shrunk. The number of people claiming jobseeker's allowance fell by 120,000 in the latest three months, a far more rapid decline than shown by the Labour Force Survey, the internationally agreed yardstick for calculating joblessnesss.

In truth, it has been impossible to take the claimant count seriously as a guide to the economy since the 1980s, when the then Conservative government changed the methodology 30 times. Only one change led to unemployment going up. The claimant count measures people who are unemployed and eligible to claim benefit. If you are not eligible you don't count.

Clearly, there has been some improvement in labour market conditions in recent months. The number of job vacancies is up and the percentage of people employed has risen, if not yet to the levels seen before the recession began. But there has also been a significant tightening of welfare rules, leading to more people being sanctioned and losing their benefits. Since the new regime was introduced last October, the number of adverse decisions (people deprived of JSA for between four weeks and 36 months) was almost two and a half times as high as in the decade 2000-2010.

Ministers say that they are providing help as well as penalties, and that those coming off the count are finding jobs. This seems unlikely. The economy is just about capable of finding employment opportunities for a workforce that is increasing in size all the time. Demand for labour remains weak.

Many of those sanctioned for minor transgressions, such as failing to show up for an appointment on time, will go back on JSA. The experience of other countries, such as the US, is that others will disappear from the system altogether and become destitute. How that is supposed to plug them back into the labour market, the avowed intention of the toughened up system, is not immediately obvious.

webTitle: British Gas owner secures £4.4bn deal with Qatar for four-year LNG supply

fields.standfirst: Cenrica agrees to import 3m tonnes of liquefied natural gas from Qatargas, as previous contract nears expiry
fields.body:
Centrica, the owner of British Gas, has turned to Qatar for its energy supplies in a £4.4bn deal that will mean than one eighth of Britain's homes being supplied with gas heating from the emirate until 2018.

The agreement announced on Wednesday underscores the UK's dependency on imported fuel as North Sea supplies run out more rapidly than predicted.

Centrica signed a deal with Qatar's national gas company, Qatargas, to import 3m tonnes a year of liquefied natural gas (LNG) – enough to supply 13% of domestic gas use, or about 3m households – from now to the end of 2018. The company will pay about £4.4bn for the fuel.

The fuel, which will be delivered by tanker to the north Kent coast, comes amid growing global competition for liquefied natural gas, with prices in Asia significantly higher than those in Europe.

In the US, meanwhile, gas prices are at historic lows, as an over-production of shale gas has led to rock bottom prices.

The role of gas in global energy supplies, and the effects on greenhouse gas emissions, are expected to form a large part of the annual global analysis, entitled World Energy Outlook, which will be published on Thursday by the International Energy Agency.

Centrica's deal extends an earlier agreement, of February 2011, between it and Qatar, one of the most gas-rich regions on Earth. More than half of the supplies agreed under that deal had already been delivered, the company said, so there was need for renewal.

The deal could be seen as an indication that prices in the UK could rise further. Centrica's previous contract with Qatargas will expire in June 2014, so the securing of new supplies will have involved a calculation about gas prices in the next five years ahead.

Sam Laidlaw, chief executive of Centrica, said: "We are delighted that we continue to deepen our relationship with Qatargas and continue to build our LNG business by integrating our positions along the gas value chain.

"It is vital that the UK has a diverse range of sources of supply to meet its energy requirements. In a competitive international market, contracts like this underpin the UK's access to global LNG supplies for the benefit of customers."

Michael Fallon, the energy minister, said: "Long-term deals of this kind, with reliable suppliers like Qatar, are vital for our future energy security."

The UK's vulnerability over imported gas was flagged up this year when technical problems with one of the main pipelines into the UK caused a temporary shutdown. The pipeline quickly reopened but the incident highlighted the fact that the UK had few gas storage facilities and frequently only a few days' supply of gas to hand.

Given the running down of the North Sea gas fields, the widespread dependency on the fuel for heating and for power generation, which is only set to increase, any fresh technical problems at the UK's supply pipelines could lead to renewed concerns.

The government this year turned down an application for public money for a new gas storage facility.

Khalid Bin Khalifa Al Thani, chief executive of Qatargas, told an energy conference in Singapore last week that the market for gas in Europe had been sluggish because of the effects of the recession.

He said: "The continued economic slowdown, coupled with the impact of European energy and climate-change policies and their unintended effects on the energy markets, has seriously dampened and even reversed in some cases the growth of gas consumption that was achieved in the continent during the last decade.

"There is no doubt that the European economies will start recovering in the near future and consequently gas consumption growth will return. While at the same time, European domestic gas production continues to decline.

"We are therefore hopeful that the serious loopholes and inconsistencies in energy and climate-change policies will be addressed and corrected soon to encourage long-term investment in gas infrastructure and enhance the energy security of Europe."

webTitle: Debenhams to display size 16 mannequins across UK stores

fields.standfirst: Retailer urges other stores to follow its lead in using mannequins that reflect the average size of women in UK
fields.body:
Debenhams has become the first department store to display size 16 mannequins in its shops, in an effort to reflect the shape of real women in Britain.

The retailer urged rival high street shops to follow its lead as it announced that larger models would be used in its 170 stores around the UK.

The introduction of size 16 mannequins comes just two months after the equalities minister Jo Swinson called for fashion stores to promote a more diverse range of women, saying it was "as if there's only one way of being beautiful".

Nearly all clothes shops in Britain use size 10 or size 8 mannequins, including Topshop and Miss Selfridge, even though the average British woman is a size 16.

Debenhams director Ed Watson said: "The average British woman is a size 16, but the high street has been showing them clothing on a mannequin that is three sizes smaller – until now.

"Having worked on this project for three years, we hope that it will help people in some small way to feel comfortable about their bodies and, crucially, that other retailers will follow."

However, there was a lukewarm response from rival outlets.

A spokeswoman for the British Retail Consortium said it was down to each individual store whether to display plus-size models.

"We won't be issuing guidance in the short term but it's an issue UK retailers take very seriously," she said.

A spokesman for Marks & Spencer said it takes a "responsible approach to visual merchandising" and pointed out that it uses size 10 models, which is above the size 8 market average.

Arcadia Group, the retail giant behind chains including BHS, Dorothy Perkins and Miss Selfridge, did not return a request for a comment.

Swinson said: "Many customers want to see more realistic images in magazines, TV and on the high street, and having mannequins that reflect and celebrate our diverse society is one way of helping to achieve this."

It is not the first time that Debenhams has defied conventional fashion promotion. The department store promoted its Principles range in 2010 with a disabled model, and more recently has banned airbrushing on swimwear advertising and run a lingerie campaign featuring a model over 50.

webTitle: Asda's Christmas advert uses snowmen to attack rivals on price

fields.bodyText: Asda is marshalling a group of snowmen to attack its rivals on price this Christmas. The supermarket's seasonal TV advert, which launches during X Factor on ITV this weekend, features thin, sad snowmen decked in yellow, blue and orange scarves to represent its three rivals, Morrisons, Tesco and Sainsbury's, while a tall happy green-hatted Asda snowman stands out from the crowd. A narrator suggests that shoppers should see the snowmen as representing potential savings, highlighting an Asda promotion which offers prices 10% cheaper than rivals. The retailer says it had spent 10% less on its "no gimmicks" media plan this year and would be investing those savings in lower prices. The unusual move to attack rivals in a Christmas campaign, when most ads look to set a cheerful mood, comes amid heavy competition between the big four supermarkets, who are nearly all seeing market share stolen by either discounters such as Aldi or quality specialists such as Waitrose and Marks & Spencer. Steve Smith, chief marketing officer, said: "We think it's more important to invest money directly into lowering the prices of all our products instead of producing costly campaigns that just keep the ad guys happy." Asda parted company with the agency which created last year's Christmas advert, which showed a mum struggling to prepare for Christmas. It drew 620 complaints to the advertising watchdog, most of which claimed it was sexist. Ben Fennell, chief executive of creative agency BBH which produced Waitrose's recent Christmas campaigns, said an attacking ad risked putting off shoppers. "It's our long-held belief that its better to talk about your strengths as a brand rather than highlight others' perceived weaknesses. Negative advertising doesn't get the consumer response you want," he said. But Asda isn't the only supermarket looking to try a different angle this Christmas. While Aldi and Lidl are both flagging up luxury goods, Sainsbury's, which launches its Christmas campaign next week, is also expected to avoid glitz while Waitrose has focused on its charitable efforts for the second year running. Fennell said: "Historically brands put their best foot forward with glitzy spectaculars but those are increasingly seen as out of step with the times." The supermarkets are all set to launch their TV ad campaigns in the next week after other major stores including Marks & Spencer, Debenhams and John Lewis kick off their campaigns this week. M&S got an early start by previewing its Believe in Magic & Sparkle ad on social media sites including Facebook on Monday and its ad will screen on television for the first time on Wednesday night.

webTitle: Greece hit by another anti-austerity general strike - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
Protests in Greece today to mark the return of the troika
• Thousands march despite heavy rain
• Photos and video from Athens
• Fears that eurozone recovery faltering
• Britain's manufacturing output jumps
fields.body:
5.27pm GMT

Closing summary

With Greece's 24-hour general strike grinding towards a close, it's time to wrap up. A quick recap.

• Greek workers have held another general strike in protest at the country's austerity programme. School staff, hospital employees, and transport workers all stopped work, bringing parts of the country to a standstill.

A reminder that, after five years of recession, anger over Greece's "reform programme" has not dissipated. Here's a full report.... and here's a list of what was hit.

• However, plans for a mass anti-austerity rally outside the Athens parliament were cancelled after heavy rain. Photos and video here...... and here.....and also here. 

• The latest economic data from the eurozone showed that private sector growthslowed last month, fuelling fears that Europe's recovery is losing momentum.

• In Britain, manufacturing output has jumped...

• ... but UK industry was hit by job cuts at BAE Systems. Analysis here

Back tomorrow, when the European Central Bank must decide whether to react to recent worrying euro area data by cutting interest rates. Until then, cheers, and thanks for the comments (as ever). GW

5.01pm GMT

Ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday - where some analysts think a rate cut is possible - and the US non-farm payrolls on Friday, European markets moved mostly higher. An exception was the UK where continuing strong data point up the prospect of an earlier than expected rate rise. The scores on the doors:

• The FTSE 100 finished down 5.15 points or 0.08% at 6741.69

• Germany's Dax ended 0.35% higher at 9040.87

• France's Cac closed 0.79% better at 4286.93

• Italy's FTSE MIB added 0.89% to 19,262.51

• Spain's Ibex climbed 0.42% to 9837.1

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a new high in early trading but has fallen back from its peak. It is currently up 0.55% or 86 points.

4.20pm GMT

Global output hits fastest pace since February 2011

Global economic activity rose last month to a 32-month high, according to JP Morgan and Markit who have crunched through the various surveys of manufacturing and service sector data released over the last week or so.

Their Global October Composite PMI rose to 55.5, from 53.6 in September, accelerating away from the 50 point mark that separates expansion from contraction.

That's despite this morning's eurozone PMI data suggesting growth slowed last month (see here).

Britain led the way, having reported the biggest jump in service sector activity since May 1997:

The UK remained the strongest performer overall, with the rate of expansion in all-industry output ticking higher to its sharpest since at least July 1996. Japan also reported a substantial series-record pace of growth, while rates of increase also improved in China, Brazil, Russia and Ireland.

The recovery in the eurozone entered its fourth successive month in October. However, the pace of expansion eased slightly, as strong growth in Ireland and steady rates of increase in France and Germany were offset by a growth slowdown in Italy and broad stagnation in Spain.

David Hensley, Director of Global Economics Coordination at JPMorgan, reckons the PMI data shows the global economy "started the final quarter on a positive footing":

All-industry output accelerated October, indicating that global GDP is on track to post a decent outcome in Q4. The broad-base of the upturn across manufacturing output and services activity is encouraging.

Here's the full release.

Updated at 4.35pm GMT

4.02pm GMT

Raining on the protesters' parade

This photo sums up the situation in Greece today, where the weather put paid to plans of a big anti-austerity rally at Syntagma Square:

Given public anger over the troika, I guess another opportunity will come along soon....

3.39pm GMT

The row over the Co-operative bank's decline and fall is taking another twist -- its former chairman is saying political interference played a part in its woes.

Paul Flowers, who quit after the discovery of a £1.5bn capital black hole sank its bid for hundreds of Lloyds branches, is testifying at the Treasury select committee.

He told MPs that a series of senior Westminster figures were keen for the Co-op to expand. That looks less than astute, given we now know the bank was struggling with its IT systems after merging with the Britannia Building Society, and in need of extra funds. 

Our City editor Jill Treanor tweets the highlights:

Updated at 3.42pm GMT

3.21pm GMT

NIESR: UK grew 0.7% in last three months

UK economic growth probably slowed slightly in October, according to the latest monthly forecast from the NIESR thinktank.

NIESR predicts that Britain's economic outlook grew by 0.7% in the three months to October, lower than the 0.8% growth seen in the July-September quarter.

If NIESR are right (and their forecasts are usually pretty accurate), this means the current level of GDP is now 5.6% above the trough of the 2008-9 recession, but still 2.3% below its pre-recession peak.

It's still the slowest recovery in at least a century:

2.45pm GMT

Martin Wolf on Germany's trade surplus

Martin Wolf is on vibrant form in the Financial Times today over the issue of Germany's chunky trade surplus.

He explains in detail why he fears that Germany is sucking demand away from its allies, particularly in the euro area, through its buoyant exports. This issue roared up the agenda last week when the US Treasury took the rare step of identifying Germany's export success as a threat to world economic stability.

Wolf writes:

Surplus countries import the demand they do not generate internally.

When global demand is buoyant, this need not be a problem provided the money borrowed by deficit countries is invested in activities that can subsequently service the debts they are incurring.

Alas, this does not happen often, partly because the deficit countries are pushed by the supply of cheap imports from surplus countries towards investing in non-tradeable activities, which do not support the servicing of international debts.

But in current conditions, when short-term official interest rates are close to zero and demand is chronically deficient across the globe, the import of demand by the surplus country is a “beggar-my-neighbour” policy: it exacerbates this global economic weakness.

Wolf then tries to blows down what he sees as another German fairytale, that the rest of the eurozone can learn from the Mittelstand and export their way to success:

It will be impossible, however, for the eurozone to achieve prosperity on the basis of export-led growth: it is too large to do so. It has to achieve internal rebalancing, as well. Hitherto, as the IMF’s October World Economic Outlook shows, it is mass shedding of labour that has raised competitiveness, and collapsing domestic demand that has reduced external deficits in the crisis-hit countries.

Thus the adjustment successes have been the other side of the coin of economic slumps and soaring unemployment. Yet, even so, the IMF does not forecast significant reductions in net liability positions. Their vulnerability will endure.

So what, in brief, is happening? The answers are: creeping onset of deflation; mass joblessness; thwarted internal rebalancing and over-reliance on external demand.

The full piece is here (FT paywall permitting....): Germany is a weight on the world 

There's also a discussion on the issue in the reader comments below: 

2.04pm GMT

BAE System's plan to cut almost 1,800 jobs across its UK sites has dampened the optimism generated by this morning's strong industrial output data.

The impact of ending 500 years of shipbuilding in Portsmouth won't be seen in the data for a while. But it highlights that Britain's manufacturing sector remains stressed -- despite the 1.2% leap in manufacturing output in September (full story here).

Economics editor Larry Elliott writes:

Clearly, this is a dreadful blow to the communities concerned, but it is not representative of what is happening to the rest of manufacturing, where official data shows output rising strongly in the past two quarters. Helped by a strong performance by the car industry, manufacturing output was 0.9% higher in the three months to September than in the previous quarter.

So if the BAE job losses are the result of specific issues facing shipbuilding and the rest of manufacturing is growing, doesn't that suggest that the UK can look forward to a broad-balanced recovery?

Not really. Sure, there has been a pick-up in manufacturing output since the spring, but production was only 1% higher in September than a year earlier, and more than 8% below its level a decade ago.

More here: The economy is growing but industry is further weakened – sound familiar?

Updated at 2.04pm GMT

1.49pm GMT

Thousands defy weather to march in Athens

As we flagged up this morning, the lousy weather in Athens sank plans for a really big rally in the Greek capital.

But thousands of workers did still march, to mark today's anti-austerity general strike.

Here's Reuters latest report: 

Thousands of striking Greek workers marched to parliament in pouring rain on Wednesday to protest against measures imposed by foreign lenders, whose inspectors are in Athens to review the country's bailout.

The 24-hour general walkout by Greece's largest public and private sector unions shut schools and disrupted flights but far fewer people took to the streets compared with previous protests as heavy downpours blanketed Athens.

The "troika" of European Commission, European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund inspectors resumed their latest bailout review on Tuesday.

"Enough is enough, we've lost our dignity." said Fotini Halikiopoulou, a 55-year old public sector employee.

"We've sacrificed everything and they (the troika) are not budging an inch."School teachers, doctors, municipal and transport workers were among the groups that joined the strike.

Air traffic controllers stopped work from 1000 to 1300 GMT and journalists stopped work for five hours.But the bleak weather and despondency among Greeks inured to protests against the erosion of jobs and benefits meant the marches largely fizzled, with two unions cancelling plans for a coordinated march to parliament because of the rain.

About 15,000 protesters, mainly from the Communist group PAME and leftist parties, rallied at central Syntagma square where police and demonstrators have clashed in the past.They held banners reading "No more sacrifices" and chanted "Don't bow down!"

KEEP FIGHTING

Labour unions fear Greece will have to impose further wage and pension cuts to meet its bailout targets in the coming years, union officials said. Greece and its lenders are at odds over the size of a projected budget hole next year.

The unions are also protesting against planned public sector job cuts and privatisations.

"We'll keep fighting," said Stathis Anestis, general secretary of the private sector union GSEE. "We warn the government that people will not tolerate any more austerity."

1.28pm GMT

Some interesting moves in the eurozone sovereign debt market today.

The yield, or interest rate, on Portugal's 10-year bonds has dropped to a five-month low of 5.94%, as traders push up the price of the securities.

And a sale of index-linked Italian bonds has seen extremely strong demand -- with traders bidding for more than €22bn of debt:

Reuters reckoned last night that this could become the biggest sale of European government debt ever... 

Updated at 2.45pm GMT

12.35pm GMT

Bloomberg is running an interesting piece today about four oil traders who are claiming in court that they can prove crude oil prices have been fixed.

The case, filed last month, argues that the system used by Platt's to set the official prices is being gamed. Allegations of this nature have been swirling for a while, but this case offers plenty of detail:

Here's a flavour:

Over 85 pages, the plaintiffs describe how the market allegedly showed that the Brent spot price was artificially driven up or down by the defendants, depending on what would profit them most in swap, futures or spot markets. They allege the defendants used methods including "spoofing" – placing orders that move markets with the intention of cancelling them later.

Platts's methodology "can be easily gamed by market participants that make false, inaccurate or misleading trades", the plaintiff traders alleged.

More here: Oil traders claim crude prices fixed

12.15pm GMT

Our news story on the job losses across BAE Systems is here: 

BAE axes 1,800 jobs and shuts down shipbuilding in Portsmouth

11.55am GMT

And here's Russia Today's video report from Athens:

11.53am GMT

Key event

Photos from the communist union's march in Athens today are flooding in:

It may feel like just another Greek strike, but the reality is that many people taking to the streets today have suffered badly for the country's long recession.

A former finance ministry cleaner, Evangelia Alexaki, told AP she is now destitute, having lost her €500 per month job in the government's layoffs:

They throw us to the streets, just like that.

Women who are 57 and 58 years old, and (too young) to get pensions or anything else. For us, this money was little but at least we could fulfill some of the family's needs. Now they're sending us to poverty.

Those lucky enough to be in work found they couldn't get to the office as transport links were closed for today's general strike: 

Updated at 11.59am GMT

11.35am GMT

It's not just the UK posting stronger than expected industrial data -- Germany just hammered expectations with a 3.3% rise in manufacturing orders in September.

Analysts had expected orders to rise by just 0.5%, after seeing them drop in August.

Overseas demand, rather than orders between German firms, drove the increase. Foreign orders jumped by 6.8% month-on-month, while domestic orders fell by 1.0%.

Orders for Capital Goods (big ticket machinery) from overseas were particularly strong - jumping by 10.2%, while domestic demand fell by 2.3%. 

The German finance ministry isn't getting carried away, saying that the impetus from abroad remained rather weak. 

And the more reliable two-month average of orders, covering August and September, rose by a less dramatic 0.4%. 

11.16am GMT

11.15am GMT

webTitle: FTSE falters ahead of Bank of England meeting, with Experian leading fallers

fields.standfirst: Investors cautious as central banks meet to set interest rate and QE policies
fields.body:
Experian led the FTSE 100 lower after the credit information business reported slightly lower than expected first half figures and unveiled an expensive looking acquisition.

Its shares dropped 81p to £11.82 as half year profits rose 2% to $573m, compared to Thomson Reuters' mean estimate of $589m.

It is also paying $850m for US healthcare data firm Passport Health Communications, which helps 2,500 hospitals across the country manage payments between patients, insurers and government schemes. A proposed $500m share buyback will now stop, after $370m was repurchased.

Last month Experian bought web fraud detection group 41st Parameter in its drive to expand internationally and into new product areas.

Analyst Tony Shepard at Charles Stanley said:

The sudden burst of M&A activity may have come as a surprise to most investors especially as Experian already has strong market positions in its markets and already has good underlying growth prospects. Normally, acquisitions are expected to provide double-digit after tax returns within 3-5 years though the latest two deals may be towards the end of this time horizon. Although the acquisition of Passport Health may enhance earnings per share on completion, the valuation remains full and we have downgraded the recommendation on Experian to hold (from accumulate).

Jefferies also cut its rating on the company, with analyst Kean Marden saying:

The debate today will centre on value creation after another sizeable acquisition. Although the Passport Health Communication transaction should be earnings per share accretive, we believe [its] earnings before interest and tax need to increase from $30m to $80m to cover its cost of capital. With the shares now trading at our price target, we downgrade from buy to hold.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 5.15 points lower at 6741.69 as recent data suggested a UK interest rate rise could come sooner than had been previously expected. Thursday sees both the latest meetings of both the Bank of England and the European Central Bank. In contrast to the UK, some analysts believe there is a chance the ECB could cut rates.

On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 hit new heights after comments from US Federal Reserve officials reinforced the idea there was unlikely to be any easing of its $85bn a month bond buying programme before the end of the year.

Barclays rose 5.65p to 254.65p despite the bank's shares going ex-dividend, after a buy note from Investec. Analyst Ian Gordon said:

Contrary to populist perceptions, we see Barclays as notably less exposed on legal/regulatory issues than peers.
We do not seek to judge the relative "guilt" of banks in relation to Libor, foreign exchange etc. However, we believe that Barclays has been financially well served for its pro-active approach on Libor. On other issues, e.g. interest rate hedging products where Barclays has been more pro-active than peers in settling redress cases, we believe it may incur higher costs for taking an apparently more constructive approach.

EasyJet climbed 11p to £12.14 even though analysts at HSBC downgraded the budget airline's shares from neutral to underweight. The bank made the cut partly on the basis that competitors such as Ryanair would change their products and marketing to be more similar to way easyJet operates. HSBC said:

Near term, we think easyJet will see stronger revenue trends than peers this winter, but we see deteriorating revenue momentum; the stock is up 94% in the past 12 months.
Long term, we think competitor moves to adopt similar product and marketing to easyJet are unlikely to match the UK business's execution, but will reduce differentiation between the companies in the eyes of consumers. We expect a large special dividend announcement at 2013 results but downgrade to underweight, with small cuts to our estimates; cut our target price to £12.25 (versus £13.70).

Elsewhere Associated British Foods - the sugar to Primark business - recovered from its falls on Tuesday in the wake of results. It added 61p to £22.69p after a number of brokers issued positive notes, including Morgan Stanley, UBS, Societe Generale and Citigroup.

Vodafone rose 2.35p to 230.60p after two more brokers suggested the mobile phone group could be a target for US group AT&T.

At Berenberg, analyst Paul Marsch issued a hold note with a 233p price target, saying:

While rising political concerns over US eavesdropping may make European Commission approval of an AT&T move more challenging, if AT&T is serious about the European mobile opportunity, it is unlikely to be put off by such concerns.
A premium offer from AT&T remains a possibility, even if a successful deal is no slam-dunk – the prospect of 265p-275p per share remains enticing.

Meanwhile Bernstein analysts raised their price target on Vodafone from 230p to 250p, factoring in a 75% chance of a deal with AT&T. They said:

Operationally and strategically, both AT&T and Vodafone are experiencing a rough patch. The possible mega merger between the two that could be a welcome distraction for both appears to have the same momentum as the Verizon/Vodafone deal earlier this year.

Centrica dropped 4.8p to 353.2p but SSE edged up 1p to £14.01 after UBS cut its price targets on the energy companies but kept its buy rating on SSE. The bank said:

We estimate the valuation impact of Labour's proposed tariff freeze is -13p on Centrica and -54p on SSE. We believe SSE is oversold compared to Centrica when valuing this and possible follow-on policies. Although not riskless, we believe SSE remains attractive relative to Centrica and EU peers, and in absolute terms. We reiterate our buy rating on SSE and our neutral call on Centrica. We now include in our forecasts the impact of a windfall tax on the carbon price floor benefit on old hydro and nuclear, to reflect this risk. Based on this and other updates, we trim our price target for SSE to 1,570p from 1,630p, and for Centrica to 355p from 370p.

Among the mid-caps Moneysupermarket.com jumped 24.7p to 179.7p after an upbeat trading statement, with fourth quarter revenues boosted by consumers switching energy suppliers since mid-October after power price rises.

Centamin, owner of the Sukari gold mine in Egypt, closed 2.5p lower at 48.3p after reporting third quarter profits of $43m, down 36% and slightly lower than some expectations. The results were hit by falling bullion prices, but the mining group said it was on course to more than meet its full year production target.

Premier Foods, the company behind the Hovis, Mr Kipling, Bisto and Sharwoods brands, put on 4.5p to 144.50p after confirming it is seeking an investor for its bread business. It said:

[Premier] has appointed [financial advisory firm] Ondra Partners to assist in developing investment options for the bread business, which include co-investment by a partner. There can be no certainty that a transaction will follow at any point in the future, but the company will provide updates as appropriate.

But analysts have mixed views, with some suggesting it would still need a rights issue of up to £300m to boost its balance sheet.

UTV was steady at 220p after announcing it had applied for a licence for a new television station in the Republic of Ireland. David O'Brien at Shore Capital said:

Following the signing of an agreement with ITV Studios Global, UTV will have exclusive broadcasting rights for ITV Studios content in the Republic, once a licence has been secured. During 2014 the company will spend on required capex to build the new station and begin to employ the workforce for UTV Ireland, thereby incurring start-up losses, before breaking even in 2015 and moving into profitability thereafter.
We think [this] represents a very sensible strategic move, one which we applaud. Our expectation is that with 2014 being a World Cup year, even after the start-up costs associated with the new channel in the Republic, we would expect some progress in profitability between 2013 and 2014.

Finally Ideagen soared nearly 19% to 26.875p after the management software group issued a positive trading update.

webTitle: Has Experian overpaid for Passport Health Communications?

fields.bodyText: Here's a quick way to send your price down: suspend your share buy-back programme and spend $850m (£527m) on buying a private equity-owned business in the US at 28 times top-line earnings. Shares in Experian, the FTSE 100 credit checking firm, naturally fell 6%, not helped either by half-year numbers that showed organic revenues rising at the bottom end of the City's expectations. The business being bought is Passport Health Communications (PHC), an operator that helps US hospitals chase payments from customers. It looks to fit well with Experian's current operations in the US; the healthcare market there is obviously huge; and the Obamacare reforms may provide PHC with a following wind. But $850m is a mighty price to pay for a business due to generate revenues of $121m this year and make just $30m in earnings before interest and tax. Next year's outcome on the latter tally should be nearer $40m. Even so, broker Jefferies calculates that the figure will have to rise to $80m before Experian creates proper value for shareholders, rather than merely obtaining a small boost to earnings per share. That process will clearly take several years, even if all goes well. That's the price for growth and leadership in an attractive market, Experian would argue. Well, yes, building a business with an eye to the long term should be applauded. But the acquisition still looks extremely pricey. More surprises of this sort and Experian's own rating, currently sky-high, will suffer.

webTitle: Portsmouth anger as BAE cuts jobs and ends historic shipbuilding industry

fields.standfirst: Workers blame both defence contractor and government for job cuts that will bring end to 500 years of shipbuilding in city
fields.body:
Twenty-one-year-old Tom Rudd had only finished his apprenticeship with BAE at HM Naval Base Portsmouth on Monday, and had been looking forward to a bright, steady future at the dockyard.

On Wednesday he strode out of Unicorn Gate, turned and gave the V-sign to the place before heading off to drink away his sorrows. "I'm not sure what the future holds now," he said. "I've done a four-year apprenticeship and thought everything was good. Now this. I think I'll sit it out now until Christmas and then maybe move abroad."

webTitle: London property market is flat, says Foxtons

fields.standfirst: Bullish London-based estate agent reports shortage of homes for sale and low mortgage availability
fields.body:
The notoriously aggressive estate agent Foxtons has reported that London property sales have been flat this year, despite government initiatives to pump up the housing market.

The chain, which has most of its 44 branches in London, said sales in the capital had been relatively flat in 2013 because of a shortage of homes for sale and low mortgage availability.

Despite the fairly lifeless market, the estate agent reported that its turnover for July to September was 18% higher than last year, hitting £41m, boosted by the seven new branches it opened in 2013.

Revenues from property sales and lettings were up 29% and 8% respectively on last year, the company said in its first management statement since it floated on the London Stock Exchange, in September.

Michael Brown, the chief executive, said the initial public offering had left the company in a strong position, with no debt.

He said: "We remain confident about Foxtons' prospects for the rest of the year but do not expect to see a significant upturn in London property sales transactions."

These comments sent Foxtons shares falling 2.5%, down 8p at 308p, in early trading on Wednesday, although this remains a 34% premium on its float price.

Foxtons, known for its hefty commissions and fleet of dark-green Mini Coopers, said it remained to be seen whether early signs of a pickup in mortgage activity and recent government initiatives, such as the Help to Buy mortgage-guarantee scheme, would translate into a significant increase in market volumes. However, "these dynamics are expected to materialise slowly", it said.

Help to Buy, which allows borrowers to put down a 5% deposit on the asking price, applies only to properties up to £600,000, meaning its effect on Foxtons' pricey central London territory will be muted.

The scheme was recently extended to all properties, after initially being targeted at new-build homes. The first phase of the scheme, offering subsidised mortgages for new homes, has helped one of the UK's biggest homebuilders, Persimmon, sell 3,000 homes.

Persimmon said visitor levels were 20% up on last year, with cancellations running at historic lows. With two months to go before the end of the year it had sold all its houses for 2013, with reservations for next year and beyond up 41% on last year.

webTitle: Mario Draghi on the back foot as ECB considers eurozone policies

fields.standfirst: After record unemployment figures, the European Central Bank president faces calls for action, but change is off agenda
fields.body:
Mario Draghi is expected to sit on his hands on Thursday when faced with calls for action. With his trademark grin, the president of the European Central Bank will bat away questions about the poor state of the eurozone economy with bland statements about a steady recovery.

He will be on the back foot after a fall in retail sales volumes across the 17-country region by 0.6% month on month, which proved a shock result for analysts who bet on eurozone growth at least maintaining its recent momentum. The decline reverses August's 0.5% increase.

Unemployment outside Germany is also a sore point. Across the eurozone the number of unemployed reached a record high in September as the ranks of the jobless swelled by 60,000 to 19.45m. The unemployment rate remained steady at 12.2%, but the previous month was revised upwards and youth unemployment in Spain rose to 56%.

And inflation continues to slide, showing a distinct lack of demand across the west. Consumer prices in the OECD area rose by 1.5% in the year to September compared with 1.7% in August. Inflation in the eurozone was running well above 2% last year. Since January it has more than halved from 2% to 0.7% in October.

Yet any prospect of an interest rate cut or something more dramatic, like a carbon copy of the Bank of England's quantitative easing, is effectively off the agenda.

As far as Draghi is concerned, his job is done. He will tinker with liquidity rules and lending costs for banks, maybe in December. Anything else, anything more fundamental, is forbidden after he provided the ultimate backstop in the summer of 2012.

No doubt he will point out that, thanks to a 0.7% increase in July, retail sales volumes still expanded in the third quarter as whole, by around 0.6% on the previous quarter. Unemployment, while rising, is a lagging indicator and not a gauge of the more settled environment today.

More importantly, Draghi believes a stimulus engineered in Frankfurt merely lets politicians off the hook. Unlike the US Fed and the BoE, the ECB is in conflict with politicians who, under pressure from their ageing electorates to protect postwar benefits and corrupt practices, will backslide at the slightest opportunity.

It is hard to underestimate how much Draghi fits into a consensus among policymakers that continental Europe is 30 years behind the US and the UK, especially when it comes to welfare commitments and flexible labour markets.

Some countries have realised how strongly this view is held in Frankfurt and how weak their own position is should they want to protest. Portugal, Ireland and Greece have entirely capitulated to the demands of free marketeers in the ECB, IMF and to a lesser extent Brussels. Only a few weeks ago Portugal's finance ministry embarked on a tour of European capitals and the US to drum up business with an offer of low taxes and flexible labour markets.

Italy and France are another matter. Both believe themselves rich enough and powerful enough to confront those who preach for a swift shift to the Anglo-Saxon model.

Italy, in particular, has responded to record unemployment with belligerent sabre-rattling in Germany's direction, accusing Berlin of double standards. Why, say the Italians, should they buy German goods if the favour is not returned? It is a real issue and not just a cover for Rome's reluctance to reform.

Without a good answer, the eurozone will enter choppy waters again, especially if an intransigent ECB is melded with a hypocritical Berlin in the minds of ordinary Italians. There could be fireworks.

webTitle: Vodafone gains on renewed talk of possible AT&T bid

fields.standfirst: Ahead of mobile phone group's figures, brokers assess chances of US takeover move
fields.body:
The idea that US telecoms group AT&T might take a tilt at Vodafone has been gaining momentum recently.

Ever since Vodafone sold its stake in its US wireless joint venture to partner Verizon for $130bn - itself a long rumoured deal - the City has been tipping Vodafone as either predator or prey. Some think the UK mobile group might look at Liberty Global, others that it could fall into the hands of AT&T.

And now two more brokers have entered the fray ahead of Vodafone's first half figures next week. At Berenberg, analyst Paul Marsch issued a hold note with a 233p price target, saying:

Worsening top-line trends will place the scrutiny on Vodafone's ability to control margins, and to balance the requirement to adhere to guidance (for a slower rate of margin decline) against the need to recover the performance gap against key peers in important markets such as Germany. Vodafone management's strategic update on the day of the results will hopefully address this challenge, in addition to other issues.
Beyond the financials, we think most investors are holding on to their Vodafone shares given 1) they provide good exposure to expected consolidation in European mobile, even if only as a bystander (note that we are cautious on this point, believing that remedies in Germany will be material); and 2) the increasing likelihood of an approach by AT&T. While rising political concerns over US eavesdropping may make European Commission approval of an AT&T move more challenging, if AT&T is serious about the European mobile opportunity, it is unlikely to be put off by such concerns. A premium offer from AT&T remains a possibility, even if a successful deal is no slam-dunk – the prospect of 265-275p per share remains enticing.

Meanwhile Bernstein analysts raised their price target on Vodafone from 230p to 250p, factoring in a 75% chance of a deal with AT&T. They said:

Operationally and strategically, both AT&T and Vodafone are experiencing a rough patch. The possible mega merger between the two that could be a welcome distraction for both appears to have the same momentum as the Verizon/Vodafone deal earlier this year.

In the market Vodafone shares have added 1.8p to 230.05p.

webTitle: BAE ends shipbuilding in Portsmouth and axes 1800 jobs

fields.standfirst: Defence secretary to make statement as company announces 940 shipbuilding jobs will go in Portsmouth and 835 in Glasgow
fields.body:
BAE Systems is cutting almost 1,800 jobs as it calls an end to more than 500 years of shipbuilding in Portsmouth. The shipyard will close by the end of 2015, with heavy job losses there and in Scotland.

The end of shipbuilding in Portsmouth brings the curtain down on a centuries old industry in a city that built the Tudor warship the Mary Rose.

The defence giant announced on Wednesday morning that 940 shipbuilding jobs will be lost in Portsmouth. A further 835 jobs are to go, mostly in Glasgow, but also in Rosyth near Dunfermline and Filton near Bristol. The jobs of an additional 3,200 BAE staff employed in maintaining and servicing Royal Navy ships at the Portsmouth naval base are not affected, although business leaders voiced fears about the knock-on effects for businesses supplying the dockyards. Union leaders described the plans to cut 1,775 jobs – far more than previously expected – as "a huge blow to Britain's manufacturing and industrial base".

The long-awaited announcement comes after BAE Systems experienced the biggest peak in UK shipbuilding since the second world war, but now faces a shortfall of work with too many staff for its next big order, the Type 26 frigates that will replace the current generation of combat ships. BAE, the UK's largest defence contractor, said Glasgow was the best location for building the Type 26 – a decision that has angered Portsmouth, while the government has been accused of preserving the Glasgow shipyards at the English city's expense to avoid damaging the pro-union campaign ahead of a vote on Scottish independence in 2014.

Speaking at prime minister's questions, David Cameron said the decision had been extremely difficult. "In Portsmouth, yes there will be job reductions, but there are many more people involved in ship servicing than in ship building."

"No one should be in any doubt of two things: under this government we will have aircraft carriers, Type 45 destroyers, the new frigates, the hunter-killer submarines."

In a separate appearance before MPs, the defence secretary Philip Hammond unveiled a contract for the government to buy three offshore patrol vessels, all-purpose oceangoing ships that will be used to tackle terrorism and piracy. These will ensure the shipyards do not stand idle before the building of larger Type 26 frigates gets underway in 2016.

Hammond said: "This is an investment not only in three ships but in this country's warship building industry. It prevents workers standing idle and sustains the vital skills needed to build the planned Type 26 frigate in the future."

This would be a cheaper option for the government than letting the shipyard stands idle, he added. Under a 2009 deal with BAE the government would have to pay a minimum of £230m a year in shipbuilding and support work.

Hammond also announced that the government would spend more than £100m on expanding the dockyard at Portsmouth to make it ready for Type 45 destroyers, a new breed of large warships that will be based in the city.

Union leaders, who are set to meet BAE executives early next week, have vowed to fight job cuts in England and Scotland. The announcement was "a huge blow to Britain's manufacturing and industrial base", said Ian Waddell of Unite. "We will have to examine the BAE business case in detail to see how we can secure a future for the workforces at both Portsmouth and in Scotland. We believe that, if this is approached in a constructive and innovative way, it can be achieved."

Waddell blamed Margaret Thatcher's government for "sowing the seeds" of current woes by closing shipyards in the 1980s, "rather than funding investment that would have allowed Britain to compete in the global marketplace for shipbuilding orders against the likes of South Korea".

Garry Graham, deputy general secretary of the Prospect union for defence specialists, argued that the UK must preserve its shipbuilding industry not only as "a key element of our defence infrastructure" but because "it is also an industry where the UK should be a world-leader".

He added: "Job losses of this scale will have a devastating impact upon local communities and economies. These are the very type of highly skilled jobs which should be leading us out of recession and helping create growth in the economy."

Hugh Scullion, general secretary of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, said he still hoped to avoid compulsory redundancies.

Political flashpoint

BAE's decision came as a huge blow to Portsmouth, which has been a UK naval base since Tudor times. Local politicians suspect political considerations ahead of the Scottish referendum next year put it in the firing line and accused Westminster of putting UK security at risk by choosing Scotland, when the break-up of the UK remains possible. "I condemn the decision to shut down the last remaining shipyard in England with the capability to build advanced surface warships," said Gerald Vernon-Jackson, leader of Portsmouth City Council. "This decision is bad for Portsmouth, with the loss of many highly-skilled jobs, but it's also bad for the defence of the UK and for the Royal Navy."

"The remaining yards with the capability to build advanced warships are in Scotland, and the referendum on Scottish independence is less than one year away. Ministers have put the defence of the UK and the future of the navy at real risk."

"We will work as hard as we can to protect jobs in Portsmouth. Portsmouth remains the home of the Royal Navy, with more than 10,000 jobs remaining in the dockyard."

Maureen Frost of Hampshire Chamber of Commerce described the loss of the shipbuilding site as "devastating news" for Portsmouth that would have a major impact on the small businesses that supply BAE Systems.

Closing one of the Scottish yards would have become a political flashpoint ahead of next year's referendum, with pro-union campaigners warning that closing the shipyards could hand victory to Alex Salmond's nationalist campaign.

The announcement was brought forward after details leaked on Tuesday, but the future of the three yards has been under threat since BAE launched a review of its maritime operations last year. The decision comes after it emerged on Monday that the Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier programme will now cost £6.2 bn, almost double the original estimates of the Labour government in 2007.

The first of the carriers, the Queen Elizabeth, is due to begin sea trials towards the end of the decade. A decision will not be taken until 2015 about whether the second carrier, Prince of Wales, will ever be operational; it could be sold or mothballed. The carriers are being built by a consortium that includes BAE.

webTitle: Lloyds pension changes trigger emergency union meeting

fields.standfirst: Accord is meeting on Friday to consider a response to plans to stop increases in the final-salary pension scheme
fields.body:
Lloyds Banking Group is facing the threat of industrial action after announcing what unions believe are "unfair and unjust" changes to the bailed-out bank's pension scheme.

The bank, in which the taxpayer owns a 32% stake, is no longer going to allow any rises in the final salary scheme. While the scheme has been closed to new members for some time, some 35,000 staff – around a third of the workforce – had been receiving annual increases of 2%.

The timing of the changes comes just 10 days before Lloyds chief executive António Horta-Osório receives an award of 3m shares, worth more than £2m, because of the rally in the share price above the 73.6p at which taxpayers break-even on their stake. The bank stands to save £60m a year from the changes.

Accord represents the majority of former staff of HBOS, which was rescued by Lloyds in 2008 as the banking crisis was taking hold. The union is holding an emergency meeting on Friday to consider a response. It could potentially conclude that it needs to ballot members for industrial action.

Ged Nichols, general secretary of Accord, said: "At a time when the economy is said to be showing signs of recovery, LBG itself is recovering its profitability, the government is considering the sale of a further tranche of shares in the bank and there is talk of resuming dividend payments to shareholders, we expect that members generally and pension scheme members in particular, will be shocked and appalled at the proposals which have been announced today."

He said the meeting on Friday could conclude that a ballot of members for industrial action is necessary if the bank pushes on with the plan after the consultation period.

Lloyds said: "Unlike a number of companies, the group has decided that it will keep its defined benefit pension schemes open to future accrual but has proposed a change to the pensionable pay cap. The group intends to consult on its proposals with active members".

The bank first introduced a cap in 2010 when it limited the pensionable pay of members to increases of the lower of 2% or the retail price index.

"The [bank] believes that the defined benefit schemes remain an important part of the employees' benefit package but wants to ensure that its pension benefits are more balanced across the group, particularly as two-thirds of the group's employees are not members of the defined benefit schemes. The group is also conscious of its obligations to ensure the viability of the schemes and its ability to meet its obligations over the long term," Lloyds said.

Lloyds also said on Wednesday that is is embarking on a review of its dealings in the £3tn a day foreign exchange market, which is under investigation by global regulators.

A growing number of banks have said they are co-operating with regulators over the potential manipulation of the market. Lloyds is not one of these but has nonetheless launched its own review. The bank said: "We are aware that a number of regulatory and enforcement authorities are investigating foreign exchange trading and as a result, we believe it is prudent to review our own foreign exchange trading over recent years and have commenced such a review. We will, of course, report anything we find to the relevant authorities and assist them as requested."

webTitle: The economy is growing but industry is further weakened – sound familiar? | Larry Elliott

fields.standfirst: The axing of 1,800 BAE jobs is a dreadful blow to those communities – but not representative of manufacturing as a whole
fields.body:
Almost 1,800 manufacturing jobs axed by BAE Systems in Portsmouth, Bristol and on the Clyde; house prices rising at an annual rate of nigh-on 7% … The economy is growing while another bit of the country's industrial base is chipped away. Haven't we been here before?

The answer is yes, many times in the past four decades, even though the current picture is slightly more complex than the bald headlines suggest. Shipbuilding has been in decline in the UK for a century, and what remains of the sector is dominated by defence orders. The supertankers that ship oil and commercial goods around the world have long been built elsewhere.

As a result, shipbuilding jobs rely on orders from the state, and the Ministry of Defence has not been exempt from the spending cuts ordered by George Osborne. Once the two aircraft carriers commissioned by the last Labour government are completed, there will not be enough work for the existing workforce. Hence the closure of Portsmouth and the job losses at Govan and Scotstoun on the Clyde, and at Filton.

Clearly, this is a dreadful blow to the communities concerned, but it is not representative of what is happening to the rest of manufacturing, where official data shows output rising strongly in the past two quarters. Helped by a strong performance by the car industry, manufacturing output was 0.9% higher in the three months to September than in the previous quarter.

So if the BAE job losses are the result of specific issues facing shipbuilding and the rest of manufacturing is growing, doesn't that suggest that the UK can look forward to a broad-based recovery?

Not really. Sure, there has been a pick-up in manufacturing output since the spring, but production was only 1% higher in September than a year earlier, and more than 8% below its level a decade ago. Factory output flatlined between 2003 and 2008, then fell off a cliff when the recession began. Service sector output, by contrast, is already comfortably above its pre-recession peak.

For a better balanced economy, Britain needs a sustained period where industrial production and exports expand more rapidly than the economy as a whole. What is not now needed is an old-fashioned housing boom, which encourages consumers to take on more debt than they can afford and which is ultimately choked off by an aggressive and indiscriminate rise in borrowing costs. News from the Halifax that house prices are 6.9% higher than a year ago suggests, regrettably, that is what we are likely to get.
